query: For agricultural landscapes, what are the most effective interventions for creating and managing aquatic habitats for amphibians?
relevant_summary: In agricultural landscapes, the most effective interventions for creating and managing aquatic habitats for amphibians include creating new ponds and wetlands, restoring existing ponds, and managing ditches. Research shows that created ponds are highly effective, with 28 studies demonstrating that amphibians consistently use newly created ponds, with 64-100% of ponds being used and 64-68% supporting reproduction. Created wetlands have also proven successful, with 15 studies showing they support similar or higher numbers of amphibian species compared to natural wetlands. Pond restoration has yielded positive results in 15 studies, with restoration increasing amphibian species numbers and maintaining breeding populations. Ditch management under agri-environment schemes significantly increases amphibian species abundance and numbers compared to conventional management. Key factors affecting success include pond permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape characteristics, distance to existing water bodies, and presence of fish. While pollution prevention and buffer strips are recommended practices, there is currently insufficient evidence to assess their specific effectiveness for amphibians in agricultural settings.

  "action_id": "880",
  "action_title": "Create wetland",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Fifteen studies investigated the effectiveness of creating wetlands for amphibians.
Five site comparison studies (including four replicated studies) in the USA compared created to natural wetlands and found that created wetlands had similar numbers of amphibian species, amphibian abundance or communities depending on depth as natural wetlands. Two of the studies found that created wetlands had fewer amphibian species or lower abundance and different communities compared to natural wetlands. One site comparison study in the USA found that created wetlands had similar numbers of species to adjacent forest. One global review and two site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA combined created and restored wetlands and compared them to natural wetlands and found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance was higher or similar, or higher in 54% of studies and similar in 35% of studies reviewed compared to natural wetlands. Three site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA found that certain amphibian species were only found in created or natural wetlands. 
One before-and-after study in Australia found that captive-bred green and golden bell frog tadpoles released into a created wetland did not establish a self-sustaining population.
Five studies (including two replicated studies) in Kenya and the USA that investigated colonization of created wetlands found that four to 15 amphibian species used or colonized the wetlands. One global review and three studies (including two replicated studies) in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and amphibian abundance in created wetlands were affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence and distance to source wetlands."
}

{
  "action_id": "869",
  "action_title": "Create ponds for amphibians",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-eight studies investigated the colonization of created ponds by amphibians in general (rather than by targeted species, which are discussed below). All of the studies found that amphibians used some or all created ponds.
Nine site comparison studies (including seven replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Spain, the UK and USA compared amphibian numbers in created and natural ponds. Five found that numbers of species or breeding species were similar or higher in created ponds, and numbers of ponds colonized were similar. Four found that species composition differed, and comparisons between abundance of individual species, juvenile productivity and size at metamorphosis differed depending on species. One found that numbers of species were similar or lower depending on the permanence of created water bodies. One found that populations in created ponds were less stable.
One review and two replicated, before-and-after studies in Denmark and the USA found that amphibians established stable populations in 50–100% of created ponds. Six replicated studies (including one randomized study) in France, the Netherlands, UK and USA found that amphibians used 64–100% and reproduced in 64–68% of created ponds, or used 8–100% and reproduced in 2–62% depending on species. One review and 15 studies (including 12 replicated studies, one of which was randomized) in Europe and the USA found that created ponds were used or colonized by up to 15 naturally colonizing species, up to 10 species that reproduced, as well as by captive-bred amphibians. Five replicated studies (including three site comparison studies) in Denmark, Estonia, France, Italy and the USA found that pond creation, and restoration in three cases, maintained and increased amphibian populations or increased numbers of species.
Seven studies (including one review) in Austria, Denmark, Poland, the Netherlands and USA found that use or colonization of or reproductive success in created ponds was affected by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds and presence of fish."
}

{
  "action_id": "878",
  "action_title": "Restore ponds",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Fifteen studies investigated the effectiveness of pond restoration for amphibians.
One replicated, before-and-after study in Denmark found that pond restoration had mixed effects on European tree frog population numbers depending on site. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that pond restoration did not increase great crested newt populations. Six replicated, before-and-after studies (including one controlled and one site comparison study) in Denmark, Estonia, Italy and the UK found that pond restoration and creation increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and ponds with breeding success. One found that numbers of species did not increase. Two before-and-after studies (including one replicated study) in Estonia found that pond restoration, along with terrestrial habitat management, maintained or increased populations of natterjack toads. One systematic review in the UK found that there was no conclusive evidence that mitigation, which often included pond restoration, resulted in self-sustaining great crested newt populations.
One small, replicated study in the USA found that pond restoration had mixed effects on spotted salamander hatching success depending on restoration method.
One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that restoration increased the number of ponds used by breeding natterjack toads. One replicated study in Sweden found that following restoration green toads only reproduced in one of 10 ponds. Three before-and-after studies (including one replicated, controlled study) in Denmark and Italy found that restored and created ponds were colonized by 1–7 species, with 6–65% of ponds colonized and 35% used for breeding."
}

query: What interventions are available for creating or providing shelter habitats for amphibians, such as refuges or hibernation sites?
relevant_summary: Creating artificial hibernacula or aestivation sites has been shown to maintain populations of great crested newts when combined with other terrestrial habitat management, with created hibernacula being used by common frog and smooth newts (Action 759). Creating refuges, including adding coarse woody debris to forest floors, has had mixed effects on individual species abundance but restoration efforts that included reintroducing coarse woody debris increased frog species, and artificial refugia were successfully used by translocated Hamilton's frogs and hellbenders (Action 772). Creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats (Action 813), adding woody debris to ponds (Action 814), and encouraging aquatic plant growth as refuge against fish predation (Action 796) are additional interventions available, though no studies have yet tested their effectiveness. Leaving coarse woody debris in forests provides habitat features, with studies showing juvenile amphibian survival was higher in wood piles compared to open areas within clearcuts (Action 843). For captive amphibians, providing enclosure furniture such as rotting logs, hollow bamboo pipes, and varied substrates promotes egg laying and breeding behavior (Action 1876).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "843",
  "action_title": "Leave coarse woody debris in forests",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that there was no significant difference in abundance in clearcuts with woody debris retained or removed for eight of nine amphibian species, but that the overall response (population, physiological and behavioural) of amphibians was more negative where woody debris was retained.
Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Indonesia found that the removal of coarse woody debris from standing forest did not decrease amphibian diversity or overall amphibian abundance, but did reduce species richness in one study.
One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that migrating amphibians used clearcuts where woody debris was retained more than where it was removed.
One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that within clearcut forest, survival of juvenile amphibians was significantly higher in piles of woody debris than in open areas, and was similar in wood piles to unharvested forest."
}

query: What factors and interventions have influenced the success of natterjack toad conservation projects in the UK?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from action documents, several key factors and interventions have influenced the success of natterjack toad conservation projects in the UK. Pond creation and restoration have been fundamental, with studies showing that pond creation along with other interventions significantly increased natterjack toad populations or maintained/increased populations at 75% of sites (Action 866). Created ponds showed lower tadpole mortality from desiccation compared to natural ponds, though higher predation mortality (Action 866). Translocation efforts have established breeding populations at 30-70% of sites, with re-establishing toads on dune or saltmarsh habitat proving more successful than on heathland (Action 859). Population increases were particularly observed with replicated translocations of wild rather than captive-bred toads (Action 859). Adding lime to reduce water acidification showed mixed results - while it helped establish translocated populations and increased species-specific habitat management effectiveness (Action 748), it also caused high tadpole mortality and pond abandonment in some cases (Action 748). Habitat management including reintroduction of grazing helped maintain or increase natterjack toad populations, with pond restoration combined with terrestrial habitat management maintaining or increasing populations (Actions 780, 878).

{
  "action_id": "3944",
  "action_title": "Employ areas of semi-natural habitat for rough grazing (includes salt marsh, lowland heath, bog, fen)",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Nine studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of employing areas of semi-natural habitat for rough grazing. Three studies were in Germany, two were in each of the UK and the Netherlands, and one was in each of China and Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (5 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One controlled study in Germany found that after 16–18 years of sheep grazing, lightly grazed and ungrazed saltmarshes had a different community of micro-moths to heavily grazed saltmarsh.
Richness/diversity (4 studies): Two replicated, site comparison studies (including one paired study) in the Netherlands and Canada found that calcareous coastal dunes and shrubsteppe managed by cattle or pony grazing for 4–13 or 6–40 years had a similar species richness of butterflies (in one case combined with all pollinators) to unmanaged land or dunes managed by cutting. One controlled study in Germany found that saltmarsh managed by light sheep grazing for 15–18 years had a greater species richness of micro-moths than moderately or heavily grazed marsh, but a similar species richness to ungrazed marsh. One replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that upland rough grassland managed by livestock grazing had a greater species richness of butterflies than permanently or partially grazed improved grassland.

POPULATION RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Abundance (7 studies): Two of four studies (including two controlled studies, one before-and-after study and two site comparison studies) in the UK, the Netherlands, China and Canada found that fenland and calcareous coastal dunes managed by cattle or pony grazing for two or 4–13 years had a higher abundance of large copper eggs and four of 13 species of butterfly than unmanaged land or dunes managed by cutting. One study found that meadow steppe grazed by cattle, goats or sheep for 1–5 years had a lower abundance of butterflies and moths than ungrazed steppe. The fourth study found that shrubsteppe grazed by cattle for 6–40 years had a similar abundance of pollinators (including butterflies) to ungrazed shrubsteppe. Two controlled studies (including one replicated, paired study) in Germany found that saltmarsh managed by light sheep grazing for 15–18 or 19–22 years had a higher total abundance of micro-moths, and of two out of seven caterpillars, than moderately or heavily grazed, or ungrazed marsh. However, one of these studies also reported that the abundance of four other caterpillars was lower in lightly or heavily grazed marsh than in ungrazed marsh. One replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that upland rough grassland managed by livestock grazing had a higher abundance of butterflies than permanently or partially grazed improved grassland.

BEHAVIOUR (2 STUDIES)

Use (2 studies): Two replicated, site comparison studies in the Netherlands found that calcareous coastal dunes and heathland managed by cattle or pony, or year-round horse and sheep, grazing for five or 4–13 years were more likely to be occupied by brown argus and Alcon large blue than unmanaged land or habitat managed by cutting, grazing and sod cutting, or summer-only cattle and sheep grazing."
}

query: What are the general outcomes and challenges associated with captive breeding programs for different amphibian groups like frogs, toads, and salamanders?
relevant_summary:
Captive breeding programs for amphibians show varied success across different groups, with frogs being the most extensively studied. For frogs (action 835), 23 of 33 studies found successful egg production in captivity by captive-bred females, though 7 studies showed mixed results with 17-50% of populations reproducing successfully. Seventeen studies successfully raised captive-bred frogs to various life stages, with egg hatching rates of 30-88%, metamorphosis survival of 75%, froglet survival of 17-51%, and 50-90% reaching adulthood. Hormone treatments (action 883) proved effective for inducing reproduction, with 9 of 10 studies showing increased sperm production in males and females producing viable eggs in 30-71% of cases. However, success varied by species, hormone type, dosage, and treatment combinations.

For salamanders (action 838), 4 of 6 studies achieved successful egg production in captivity, with some captive-bred females reproducing. Larval development, body condition, and survival varied based on water temperature, density, and whether animals were raised in laboratory versus semi-natural conditions. Environmental factors proved critical across groups, with breeding success depending on temperature simulation, wet/dry season replication, and appropriate enclosure furniture including calling sites and breeding areas (actions 835, 1876).

Release outcomes showed mixed results (action 871), with 41% of captive-bred amphibian release programs demonstrating multi-generational breeding in the wild, 29% showing some breeding evidence, and 12% showing survival after release. Key challenges include species-specific differences in reproduction difficulty, dependency on environmental conditions like temperature and seasonal changes, and low survival rates in some populations. Head-starting programs (action 881) showed promise, with 6 of 10 studies establishing breeding populations or increasing existing populations, though adult survival varied from 1-17% over four years in some cases.

{
  "action_id": "835",
  "action_title": "Captive breeding frogs",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Thirty-three studies investigated the success of breeding frogs in captivity.
Twenty-three of 33 studies, three of which were reviews and 30 replicated studies, across the world found that amphibians produced egg in captivity, in four cases by captive-bred females. Seven found mixed results, with some species of frogs or 17–50% of captive populations  reproducing successfully in captivity, but with other species difficult to maintain or raise to adults. One found that frogs did not breed successfully in captivity and another that all breeding frogs died. Seventeen of the studies found that captive-bred frogs were raised successfully to hatching, tadpoles, froglets or adults in captivity. One found that froglet survival was low and another that three species were not successfully raised to adulthood.
Four replicated studies (including one small study) in,Canada, Fiji, Hong Kong and Italy found that 30–88% of eggs hatched or survival to metamorphosis was 75%, as froglets was 17–51% or to adults was 50–90% in captivity.
One review and four replicated studies (including two small studies) in Germany, Italy and the USA found that reproductive success of frogs in captivity depended on temperature or a simulated wet and dry season, but not on whether frogs were housed in high or low maintenance facilities. Three replicated studies (including one small study) in Germany, Australia and Canada found that egg or tadpole development in captivity was affected by parental care, density or temperature."
}

{
  "action_id": "881",
  "action_title": "Head-start amphibians for release",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-two studies head-started amphibians from eggs and monitored them after release.
Six of 10 studies (including five replicated studies) in Denmark, Spain, the UK and USA and a global review found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding frog populations or increased populations of frogs or toads. Two found mixed results with breeding populations established in 12 of 17 studies reviewed or at two of four sites. Two found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population. For five of the studies, release of captive-bred individuals, translocation or habitat management were also carried out.
Nine of 10 studies (including nine replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Europe and the USA found that head-started amphibians released as tadpoles, metamorphs or adults metamorphosed successfully, tended to survive the first season, winter or year or bred successfully. One found adult survival was 1–17% over four years and one found limited breeding following the release of adults.
Four replicated studies in Australia, the UK and USA found that frog survival to metamorphosis and size at metamorphosis was greater and time to metamorphosis shorter in head-started compared to wild animals. One replicated study in Canada found that young head-started leopard frogs were smaller than those in the wild. One replicated study in Australia found that corroboree frog tadpoles released earlier had higher survival, but metamorphosed two weeks later than those released a month later.
Three studies (including one replicated study) in the USA only provided results for head-starting in captivity. Two found that Houston toad eggs could be captive-reared to tadpoles, but only one successfully reared adults. Three studies (including two replicated studies) in Canada and the USA found that during head-starting, amphibian growth rate, size, stress levels and survival was affected by the amount of protein provided, housing density or enclosure location. One found that mass, stress levels and survival were not affected by the amount of food or habitat complexity."
}

query: As an alternative to creating entirely new ponds, what actions can be taken to restore or enhance existing water bodies for amphibians?
relevant_summary: As alternatives to creating new ponds, several actions can be taken to restore and enhance existing water bodies for amphibians. Pond restoration has shown mixed results, with some studies finding increased species numbers and populations, while others found no increase in species numbers or failed to increase great crested newt populations. Tree canopy removal can reduce pond shading to improve conditions for amphibians. Water level regulation through maintaining or draining ponds has been shown to increase natterjack toad populations, maintain newt populations, and significantly increase amphibian abundance and species numbers. Adding lime to water bodies has had mixed effects, with some studies showing increased survival and breeding success, while others resulted in tadpole mortality and pond abandonment. Pond deepening, de-silting, and re-profiling have resulted in establishment of breeding populations of great crested newts and increased populations of common frogs and tree frogs, while also maintaining newt populations and increasing European fire-bellied toad and natterjack toad numbers. Augmenting ponds with groundwater to reduce acidification has also been suggested as a restoration technique, though no studies have tested its effectiveness.

query: Which vegetation management practices are most likely to benefit amphibian populations, and which are likely to be ineffective or harmful?
relevant_summary:
Thinning trees within forests shows mixed effects on amphibians compared to clearcutting, with five studies (including four replicated and/or controlled studies) in the USA finding that thinning generally results in better outcomes than clearcutting. Two studies found higher amphibian abundance (except for ensatina salamanders) or less negative overall responses in thinned forest, while two found mixed effects depending on species, life stage, and time since harvest. However, a meta-analysis of 24 North American studies found that partial harvest (including thinning) still decreased salamander populations overall. One study found thinning decreased body condition of ensatina salamanders 10 years after harvest.

For grazing management, one replicated, controlled study in the UK found that grazed plots had lower abundance of common toads compared to ungrazed plots, though five studies (including four replicated studies) in Denmark, Estonia, and UK found that habitat management including reintroduced grazing maintained or increased populations of green toad, natterjack toad, and common toad populations. One before-and-after study in the USA found similar amphibian species decline under both traditional and intensive cattle stocking.

Changing mowing regimes shows some positive effects, with one before-and-after study in Australia finding that restoration including reduced mowing increased numbers of frog species. Three studies evaluating wetland management by grazing or cutting for butterflies and moths found mixed effects, with one Swiss study showing mowing increased butterfly species richness compared to cattle grazing in fens, but two Dutch studies found reduced survival for large copper butterflies in recently cut fens.

There is no evidence found for the effects of encouraging aquatic plant growth as refuge against fish predation on amphibian populations.

query: What key factors are associated with the success or failure of amphibian colonization and breeding in newly created ponds?
relevant_summary: Based on evidence from multiple studies across different countries, several key factors significantly influence the success or failure of amphibian colonization and breeding in newly created ponds. Pond permanence is a critical factor, with studies showing that numbers of species colonizing created ponds can be similar or lower depending on the permanence of created water bodies. Fish presence represents a major negative factor, with research demonstrating that draining ponds to eliminate fish significantly increases numbers of amphibian species, and pond drying to eliminate fish increases breeding success of frogs and newts. Vegetation cover and shading also play important roles, with canopy removal affecting breeding success of different species differently - it enabled translocated garlic toads to establish breeding populations, but did not increase hatching success of spotted salamanders in another study. Landscape context matters significantly, with pond age, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape characteristics, distance to existing ponds, and permanence all affecting amphibian use, colonization, and reproductive success in created ponds. Water level management is crucial, with studies showing that maintaining appropriate water levels enabled successful breeding by species like dusky gopher frogs, while draining ponds in particular seasons significantly increased abundance and species numbers. The success rates for amphibian establishment are highly variable, with studies reporting that amphibians established stable breeding populations in 50-100% of created ponds, used 64-100% of created ponds for reproduction, but individual species success rates varied dramatically from 2-62% depending on the species. Pond creation alone may not guarantee success, as some studies found that populations in created ponds were less stable than natural populations.

query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of different direct treatments for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis?
relevant_summary: Direct treatments for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis have shown varying levels of effectiveness. Antifungal treatments, particularly itraconazole, have demonstrated the strongest evidence for effectiveness, with six of eight studies (including two randomized, replicated, controlled studies) in Japan, Tasmania, the UK and USA finding that itraconazole effectively cured amphibians of chytridiomycosis. However, six studies reported that specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians. Temperature treatment has also shown promise, with four of five studies (including four replicated, controlled studies) in Australia, Switzerland and the USA finding that increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30-37C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis. Antibacterial treatments showed mixed results - two studies in New Zealand and Australia found that treatment with chloramphenicol antibiotic ointment or solution cured green tree frogs and Archey's frogs, while another study found that trimethoprim-sulfadiazine increased survival time but did not cure blue-and-yellow poison dart frogs. Treatments using antifungal skin bacteria or peptides showed limited effectiveness, with three of four studies finding no reduction in infection rate or death, though three studies did find reduced weight loss. Immunization with formalin-killed chytrid fungus did not significantly reduce infection rate or mortality in mountain yellow-legged frogs. A field study in Mallorca found that treating wild midwife toads with fungicide along with pond drying reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis.

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of retaining habitat features like riparian buffers, coarse woody debris, and snags during timber harvesting?
relevant_summary:
Studies have documented mixed effects of retaining habitat features during timber harvesting. Riparian buffer strips showed mixed effects on amphibian abundance depending on species and buffer width, with six of 11 studies finding mixed effects depending on species or existing downed wood volume, four finding similar abundance and species composition to unharvested forest, and two finding lower numbers than in unharvested forest. Two of four studies found greater amphibian species numbers and abundance in wider riparian buffers (Action ID: 747).

For coarse woody debris, two replicated controlled studies found no significant difference in abundance for eight of nine amphibian species between clearcuts with debris retained versus removed, though overall amphibian response was more negative where debris was retained. One study found juvenile amphibian survival was significantly higher in woody debris piles than open areas within clearcuts. For mammals, three studies showed mixed results, with one finding more small mammal species groups in felled areas with woody debris, while two found no increase in small mammal numbers with retained debris (Action ID: 843, 2647).

Regarding snags/standing deadwood, two studies found mixed effects on reptile diversity and abundance when adding snags and woody debris compared to no manipulation or debris removal. query: What actions are available to mitigate the impacts of agricultural pollution on amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence found, several actions are available to mitigate agricultural pollution impacts on amphibian populations. One controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that managing ditches increased common toad numbers, and a replicated, site comparison study in the Netherlands found that amphibian species numbers and abundance were significantly higher in ditches managed under agri-environment schemes compared to conventional management (Action 749). Another study in Taiwan found that halting pesticide use along with habitat management increased a population of Taipei frogs (Action 832). Creating wetland habitats has been extensively studied, with fifteen investigations showing that created wetlands can support similar or higher numbers of amphibian species and abundance compared to natural wetlands, though success depends on factors such as wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence, and distance to source wetlands (Action 880). However, one replicated, controlled study in the USA found that planting riparian buffer strips along streams did not increase amphibian abundance, numbers of species, or the ratio of adults to tadpoles (Action 819). Additionally, there is currently no evidence available for the effectiveness of preventing pollution from agricultural lands or sewage treatment facilities entering watercourses (Action 802), or establishing riparian buffers to reduce pollutants reaching water bodies (Action 2882) specifically for amphibian populations.

query: How effective are conservation actions such as legal protection, habitat creation, and translocation for great crested newt populations in the UK?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from UK studies, conservation actions for great crested newts show mixed effectiveness. Legal protection has been ineffective at protecting populations during development, with reviews finding that legal protection did not effectively protect great crested newt populations (Action 779), although the number of mitigation licences issued increased to over 600 in England and Wales over 10 years. Habitat creation through pond creation shows more positive results, with three studies finding that great crested newts established breeding populations at 57-75% of created ponds, and up to 88% of created ponds were colonized by translocated or naturally colonizing newts (Action 863). However, a systematic review found no conclusive evidence that pond creation resulted in self-sustaining populations. Translocation effectiveness is variable, with four of six studies finding that translocated great crested newts maintained or established breeding populations, but populations were present one year after release in only 37% of cases, and within three years breeding failed in 48% of ponds (Action 858). One systematic review found no conclusive evidence that mitigation including translocations resulted in self-sustaining populations. Artificial hibernacula creation shows limited effectiveness, with one study finding they were used by common frogs and smooth newts but not great crested newts (Action 759).

query: What is the evidence regarding the long-term success and timeframes for amphibian populations to respond to habitat restoration, such as replanting or vegetation clearance?

  "action_id": "2550",
  "action_title": "Remove vegetation by hand/machine",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty studies evaluated the effects on mammals of removing vegetation by hand or machine. Eleven studies were in the USA, and one each was in Canada, South Africa, Israel, Norway, Portugal, France, Spain, the Netherlands and Thailand.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): A site comparison study in the USA found that mechanically clearing trees within woodland reduced small mammal diversity.

POPULATION RESPONSE (12 STUDIES)

Abundance (11 studies): Eight of 11 site comparison or controlled studies (nine of which were replicated), in the USA, Israel, Portugal, Spain and the Netherlands, found that clearing woody vegetation or herbaceous and grassland vegetation benefitted target mammals. Population or density increases were recorded for small mammals, European rabbits and Stephens’ kangaroo rat while black-tailed prairie dog and California ground squirrel colonies were larger or denser and Utah prairie dog colonies established better than in uncleared areas. Two studies found mixed results of clearing woody vegetation, with hazel dormouse abundance declining, then increasing and small mammal abundance increasing, then declining in both cleared and uncleared plots alike. One study found no effect of scrub clearance from sand dunes on habitat specialist small mammals.
Survival (1 study): A replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that mechanical disturbance of woody vegetation within forest (combined with reseeding, follow-up herbicide application and further seeding) increased overwinter survival of mule deer fawns.

BEHAVIOUR (8 STUDIES)

Use (8 studies): Four of seven studies (of which six were site comparisons or controlled), in the USA, Canada, Norway, France and Thailand, found that areas cleared of woody vegetation or herbaceous and grassland vegetation were utilized more by mule deer, reindeer, mouflon and gaur. One study found that clearing woody vegetation promoted increased use by white-tailed deer in some but not all plots, one found that it did not increase use by mule deer and one found that carrying out a second clearance on previously cleared plots did not increase use by white-tailed deer. A before-and-after study in South Africa found that clearing woody vegetation from shrubland increased wildebeest and zebra abundance following subsequent burning but not when carried out without burning whilst other mammals did not show consistent responses."
}

One before-and-after study in Australia found that captive-bred green and golden bell frog tadpoles released into a created wetland did not establish a self-sustaining population.
Five studies (including two replicated studies) in Kenya and the USA that investigated colonization of created wetlands found that four to 15 amphibian species used or colonized the wetlands. One global review and three studies (including two replicated studies) in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and amphibian abundance in created wetlands were affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence and distance to source wetlands."
}

Four studies evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of abandoning cropland with the expectation that freshwater marshes or swamps would recover spontaneously. There was one study in each of Spain, South Korea, China and Japan. The studies involved former rice fields, soybean fields or pastures.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY

Community composition (2 studies): Two site comparison studies in South Korea and Japan reported that the overall plant community composition in abandoned cropland became more like natural swamps and/or marshes over time.

Overall abundance (2 studies): One site comparison study in China found that vegetation biomass in abandoned soybean fields was lower than in natural wet meadows after three years, similar to natural wet meadows after six years, and higher than in natural wet meadows after 12 years. query: What management options are available to mitigate the impacts of timber harvesting on forest amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: Management options available to mitigate the impacts of timber harvesting on forest amphibian populations include retaining riparian buffer strips during timber harvest, which has shown mixed effectiveness with some studies finding higher amphibian abundance with buffers, and others finding mixed effects depending on species and buffer width. Using shelterwood harvesting instead of clearcutting has shown more consistent benefits for salamanders, with studies finding higher or similar abundance compared to clearcutting, and a meta-analysis showing smaller population reductions than clearcutting. However, shelterwood harvesting still decreases salamander abundance compared to no harvesting in most cases.

query: What are the most beneficial actions for creating or restoring aquatic habitats for amphibians?
relevant_summary: The most beneficial actions for creating or restoring aquatic habitats for amphibians include pond creation and restoration, wetland restoration and creation, and engaging landowners in habitat management. Pond creation has been extensively studied with 28 investigations showing amphibians used created ponds, with 64-100% of ponds used for reproduction and establishment of stable populations in 50-100% of cases. Pond restoration showed mixed results, with some studies finding increased amphibian species numbers and breeding success, while others found no increase in populations. Wetland restoration and creation also proved effective, with 89% of cases showing similar or higher amphibian abundance compared to natural wetlands, and 4-15 amphibian species colonizing created wetlands. Engaging landowners and volunteers in aquatic habitat management increased natterjack toad and Taipei frog populations, with programs restoring up to 1,023 ponds or over 11,500 km2 of habitat. Habitat connectivity is also important, as retaining native vegetation corridors maintained populations of eight of 13 frog species over 20 years. Success of these interventions depends on factors such as pond permanence, vegetation cover, distance to existing ponds, and surrounding landscape characteristics.

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of using chemical treatments for amphibian conservation?
relevant_summary: Chemical treatments in amphibian conservation have shown mixed results. For antifungal treatments against chytridiomycosis, 12 of 16 studies found that treatments cured or increased survival of amphibians, with 6 of 8 studies finding itraconazole specifically effective at curing chytridiomycosis. However, 6 studies also found that specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians. Hormone treatments have been used to induce sperm and egg release in amphibians. For chemical pollution prevention, one study found that halting pesticide use along with habitat management increased a population of Taipei frogs. Salt treatment showed benefits, with one study finding that adding salt to ponds kept green and golden bell frogs free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months. However, treating wild midwife toads with fungicide along with pond drying reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis. Studies on pesticide reduction showed that agricultural areas managed with reduced or no pesticide, herbicide, or fertilizer input generally had greater species richness and abundance of butterflies and moths compared to areas with conventional chemical applications.

Eleven studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use generally. Three studies were in the UK, two were in each of the USA and Germany, one was in each of Spain, Mexico and Switzerland, and one was a systematic review across Europe.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (10 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (10 studies): Eight studies (including one replicated study, two controlled studies, one randomized study, five site comparison studies, and one systematic review) in the USA, Europe, the UK, Spain, Mexico and Switzerland found that orchards, crop edges, farms, vineyards, replanted Douglas fir stands, coffee plantations and agricultural landscapes managed with less frequent, reduced or no pesticide, herbicide, fertilizer or unspecified chemical input (sometimes along with other agri-environment scheme options or less intensive management) had a greater species richness of adult butterflies and moths, or caterpillars (in one case along with other leaf-eating arthropods), than areas with more frequent or conventional chemical applications. However, one of these studies found that species richness was not affected by the number of pesticide applications in the year of study, only in the previous three years, and another of the studies also found that vineyards managed with reduced insecticide and herbicide application had a similar species richness of moths to conventionally managed vineyards. Two replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled study and one site comparison study) in the UK and Germany found that unfertilized grassland had a similar species richness of butterflies and moths, but greater species richness of specialist moths, to fertilized grassland.

POPULATION RESPONSE (9 STUDIES)

Abundance (9 studies): Six studies (including one replicated study, one controlled study, one randomized study, four site comparison studies, and one systematic review) in Europe, the UK, Germany, Mexico and Switzerland found that crop edges, farms, a hay meadow, coffee plantations and agricultural landscapes managed with less frequent, reduced or no pesticide, insecticide, fungicide, herbicide, fertilizer or unspecified chemical input (sometimes along with other agri-environment scheme options or less intensive management) had a higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths, or caterpillars, than areas with more frequent or conventional chemical applications. However, one of these studies found that abundance was not affected by the number of pesticide applications in the year of study, only in the previous three years, and another of these studies also found that a hay meadow with no herbicide applications had a similar abundance of caterpillars to a meadow where herbicide was used, and a meadow with no fertilizer applications had a lower abundance of caterpillars than a meadow where fertilizer was applied in one of two sampling sessions. Three replicated studies (including two randomized, controlled studies and one site comparison study) in the UK, Germany and the USA found that unfertilized grassland and replanted Douglas fir stands with limited or no herbicide applications had a similar abundance of adult butterflies and caterpillars, and adult moths, to fertilized grassland and stands with more herbicide applications.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Use (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Germany found that unfertilized or lightly fertilized grasslands were preferred to heavily fertilized grasslands by 7 out of 58 species of moth, but 12 of 58 species preferred more heavily fertilized grasslands."

query: As an alternative to treating infected individuals, what environmental management actions can help control chytridiomycosis in the wild?
relevant_summary: Environmental management actions for controlling chytridiomycosis in the wild include adding salt to ponds, as one study in Australia found that a population of green and golden bell frogs remained free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months after salt addition. Pond management techniques such as drying ponds and applying fungicidal treatment have also been tested, with one study in Mallorca finding that while these measures reduced infection levels in midwife toads, they did not completely eradicate chytridiomycosis. Temperature management by increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30-37C for over 16 hours has shown promise, with four of five studies finding this cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis. Additionally, using zooplankton to remove chytrid zoospores has been proposed as an environmental control method, though no studies have yet tested this approach.
